Classify the following problem into the corresponding category of Bloom's taxonomy:
There are 5 yellow pegs, 4 red pegs, 3 green pegs, 2 blue pegs, and 1 orange peg to be placed on a triangular peg board. In how many ways can the pegs be placed so that no (horizontal) row or (vertical) column contains two or more pegs of the same color?  (Any two pegs of the same color are indistinguishable.)

[asy]
draw((0,0)--(5.5,0)--(0,5.5)--cycle);
for (int i=0; i<5; ++i) {
dot((0.5,i+0.5));
}
for (int i=0; i<4; ++i) {
dot((1.5,i+0.5));
}
for (int i=0; i<3; ++i) {
dot((2.5,i+0.5));
}
for (int i=0; i<2; ++i) {
dot((3.5, i+0.5));
}
dot((4.5,0.5));
[/asy]<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Factual

The student needs to remember the formula for combinations, specifically C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!), and apply it to the problem at hand, which involves a standard deck of 52 cards. The problem does not require the student to think conceptually about the relationships between different elements, nor does it involve procedural knowledge of how to approach the problem. It simply requires the recall of a mathematical fact or formula.
